newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end at 6-year high, but only barely.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end at 6-year high, but only barely.

text.p: Taiwan share prices inched up slightly to six-year high close, as hopes for an imminent end to a 47-year ban on Taiwan-China shipping outweighed profit-taking amid signs that a big 1997 rally was slowing.
The benchmark stock index ended with a scant 13.08 point or 0.16 percent gain at 8,268.15 after a surging as high as 8,299.14 and dipping as low as 8,179.74.

Thursday's close surpassed the 8,255.07 finish on March 12 to marked the index's highest close since it reached 8,569.55 on May 15, 1990. Turnover was hectic but, at T$165.1 billion, somewhat less than Wednesday's sizzling T$179.57 billion.
Most major sectors fell, including textile, food and paper shares. Transports and cements gained 0.46 and 1.44 percent.

Transport shares were sharply higher most of the day on reports that China would allow Taiwan shippers to sail direct Taiwan-China routes, ending a 47-year-old ban, but profit-taking by short-term investors eroded the gains, brokers said.
Associated Transport rose to its uplimit of seven percent to T$36.7, gaining T$2.4., while Yang Ming Marine gained T$0.8 to T$38.8.
Chia Hsin Cement gained T$1.5 to T$31. Chien Tai cement earned T$0.9 at T$22.8, brokers said.
"Despite resistance pressure at 8,400, investors were still confident in the market and quickly bought in when share prices eased lower at midsession," said Nomura Securities' Amy Huang.
Brokers said anticipation of a property rebound and direct shipping links with China staved off a downturn for the index.
"Investors hold an optimistic view toward transport shares on the improving future of shipping links with mainland China," Chen Han-chung, manager of Yungli Securities said.
Investors' anticipation of a property market recovery after years of recession was the main factor behind the cement sector rise, brokers said.
